abstracts.cdata!:
The Forestry Project for the Republic of
            Senegal achieved mixed results. The project failed to
            achieve its original production objectives due to
            lower-than-expected rainfall and unfavorable soil
            conditions. The project was reoriented away from pure
            production objectives toward the reconstitution and
            protection of the natural, local vegetative cover. Except
            for chronic financial problems, project implementation was
            successful after reorientation. The project also generated a
            number of hard-to-quantify benefits, including advances in
            forest cover reconstitution techniques; excellent training
            of forest technicians and extension workers; and an
            innovative approach to engage the rural population in
            reafforestation and soil management. Performance under the
            natural forest management and the planning, monitoring, and
            economic studies component was disappointing, while the
            training component activities were successful. Although the
            educational benefits of the rural forestry and training
            component are sustainable, the majority of
            directly-productive activities will likely not be
            sustainable without further assistance. The Bank bears
            responsibility for overly optimistic project objectives and
            a somewhat inappropriate assessment of project risks. While
            the Bank responded quickly and showed commendable
            flexibility in the reorientation, its supervision missions
            were lacking in several areas. The Borrower provided very
            proficient and highly motivated staff. However, there were
            problems with disbursement of counterpart funds, slow
            processing of requests, and division of responsibility which
            led to delays. The project yielded a number of lessons.
            Pedological and climatic conditions in Senegal's
            Centre-Est do not allow for cost-effective wood production
            in industrial plantations, but other methods do exist. Yet,
            these remain too expensive under the current Senegalese wood
            price system and are unlikely to meet increasing demand.
            Planting in and around farmland can be profitable, although
            these markets may quickly be saturated. Forests cannot be
            viewed as mere wood reserves, but must be managed as an
            integrated system of resources. The rural population is
            increasingly aware of the dangers of wood resource
            degradation and can be effectively mobilized to contribute
            to natural resource management.
